abstracts.cdata!:
The experience with the Education
            Project for the Ivory Coast has been mixed. It is too early
            at this stage to attempt a full evaluation of project
            outcomes as the various institutions have been in operation
            for too short a time and a later review of these outcomes is
            needed. Even so, a few lessons can be learned from the
            project at this time. First, severe problems in project
            implementation arose because the views of user ministries
            were insufficiently taken into account during project
            generation and appraisal. Second, the Borrower's
            reluctance to adapt to the Bank's accommodation
            standards has resulted in school enrollment targets not
            being reached. Third, closer coordination between RMWA and
            Bank headquarters was needed in the supervision of the
            project. Fourth, a cheap source of power for television
            receivers is needed for the establishment of an economical
            ETV system. Finally, changes in curricula are difficult to
            effect and need close attention by Bank missions.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project consists of: (a)
            construction and equipment of 11 schools with an enrollment
            capacity of 6500 places of which 6050 would be new, as
            follows: 3 primary teacher training colleges; 3 general
            secondary schools; 2 secondary technical schools; 1
            vocational school for adult accelerated training; and 2
            post-secondary technical schools, one for agriculture and
            one for industry and commerce; (b) consultant services for
            design of school buildings and supervision of construction;
            (c) technical assistance for a study to improve utilization
            of existing and future secondary schools and to introduce
            modern curricula; (d) provision of about 29 man-years of
            fellowships; (e) construction and furnishing of an
            Instructional Television (ITV) production center and of a
            central maintenance building; and (f) management and
            evaluation consultant services for ITV.

abstracts.cdata!:
This is a partial transcript of the
            Board discussion concerning the First Education Project in
            the Ivory Coast.  The project has two noteworthy features.
            The first time the Bank will be directly involved in the
            field of primary education and also, for the first time, the
            Bank will participate in the financing of instructional
            television. The Ivory Coast provides particularly justified
            grounds for these innovations. The reason is that the
            country has achieved remarkable economic performance since
            independence in 1960. Primary education has continued to
            prepare primary school leavers exclusively for secondary
            school entrance and for white collar jobs. In so doing it
            has failed to respond to the real needs of the economy. The
            Government is aware of these shortcomings and has drawn up a
            long-term educational program based on a new policy. The
            main objectives of this policy are to improve the efficiency
            of the system and to expand the output of technical,
            vocational, agricultural education; and at the secondary and
            post-secondary levels.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Project for Cote
            d'Ivoire consists of: (a) construction and equipment of
            11 schools with an enrollment capacity of 6500 places of
            which 6050 would be new, as follows: 3 primary teacher
            training colleges; 3 general secondary schools; 2 secondary
            technical schools; 1 vocational school for adult accelerated
            training; and 2 post-secondary technical schools, one for
            agriculture and one for industry and commerce; (b)
            consultant services for design of school buildings and
            supervision of construction; (c) technical assistance for a
            study to improve utilization of existing and future
            secondary schools and to introduce modern curricula; (d)
            provision of about 29 man-years of fellowships; (e)
            construction and furnishing of an Instructional Television
            (ITV) production center and of a central maintenance
            building; and (f) management and evaluation consultant
            services for ITV.
